characters: A TRAIN PULLING INTO PENN STATION, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
INT. HOTEL LOUNGE. NIGHT, (SAME HOTEL AS P. 71)
A PLANE TAKING OFF AT DAWN, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
EXT. NEW YORK SKYLINE. EVENING, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
EXT. DECK OF COBALT COCKTAIL LOUNGE. EVENING
INT. HOTEL LOUNGE. DAY, (SAME HOTEL AS SC 93)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of people BUZZING in excitement -- reporters, officials, men in dark suits. Occasional flashes of color women in brighter attire elbow through the crowd. Screens hover overhead, each alive with rows of numbers. Traders shouting orders, flashbulbs popping, constant videotaping on cell phones.

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: What a historic day Eric! And now we pull back, realizing that the chaos at the sto exchange is actually happening on a TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the face of a beautiful woman, her sharp eyes focu on the screen. This is NAOMI, early 40’s, poised, tough, brilliant, and pissed off by what she’s watching. On the TV, a bubbly female reporter holds court at the ed of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: You’ve seen the hordes of people cheering, just now I think we had the biggest WOO I’ve heard all day. Nobody expected Dynacorps stock to climb to 47-- An impersonal sleek hotel room. Naomi gazes at the TV, as gets ready to head out for a day of meetings. A second reporter, back at the studio.

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: This IPO is certainly one of the biggest we've seen this year-- Naomi shuts off the TV. She keeps her gaze on the empty screen a moment. She exha

dialogues.speaker: TECH CEO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, what happened with Dynacorps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAOMI wines and dines an eager 25-year-old male CEO of a company. He talks with his mouth full.  2 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: They elected to work with Channing Trust for the offering.

dialogues.speaker: TECH CEO
dialogues.text: But you had a long history with those guys, didn’t you? She meets his gaze. Around them, chopsticks fly over colo platters. TECH CEO (CONT’D) Word is you low-balled them on pricing.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Pricing is a judgment call.

dialogues.speaker: TECH CEO
dialogues.text: But ultimately they IPO’d at the higher price.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Listen Doug, I’ve taken 9 Silicon Valley companies public in the last five years. You want to talk about the one I didn’t take to the finish line? Naomi leans forward, enjoying herself.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's what nobody wants to admit. Everything is a judgment call. And yes, you need to trust your banker, because this is a partnership. You guys are the innovators, who can build technology the rest of us are not even imagining. But without funding, that’s just tinkering ina garage. I work for the largest investment bank in the world. And we both know I found you guys capital when you were a couple of kids with a laptop and a dream. So we can talk about last year’s IPO calendar, or we can talk about how to grow your company so you can build technology that’s going to transform people’s lives. The Ceo nods, impressed.  3 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You try the Tasmanian Sea Trout? Naomi smiles and pops one in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEW YORK SKYLINE. EVENING, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: A plane lands against the backdrop of the shimmering buildings of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi gazes at the lights of the city gliding by from the back of a luxury car. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 6 We track through the apartment, finding the remnants of dinner for two, takeout on fancy plates, an empty wine bottle, a pair of discarded high heels. On the balcony, MICHAEL pours amber scotch into a glass. is late 40s, handsome and charismatic. He hands the glass Naomi. Michael is sharp; nothing gets past this guy. They are in Michael's dimly lit enormous loft apartment. Michael plays with Naomi’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You smell like the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You smell like noodles. Singapore?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hong Kong. Naomi takes a sip of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: What have you heard?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m in a completely different division of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You’re on the exec. Restructuring? Randall’s retiring? He hesitates, gives in.  4 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: They’1l need a new global head.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Now you’re beyond my scope.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I’m a top producer for this firm.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Naomi. He tucks her hair behind her ear.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You lost a major client. She looks at him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Are you saying I should be worried? He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. You’ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: It’s late. She slips into her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Stay.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I’m exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We’ll crash early. What’s so good about your bed anyway? She looks at him, brings her face close to his, seductive

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Threadcount. And she’s out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 Green Rev. (07/15/15) INT. NAOMI’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM. NIGHT 7 An enormous bed with rumpled luxury sheets. The bed is em Through a doorway we see Naomi in an office alcove, typin the computer in a silk nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi walks past a conference room with 10 senior male bankers in an intense conversation. One of them glances u her through the glass. Suddenly she feels self-conscious- could they be talking about her? She moves on briskly. INT. NAOMI’S OFFICE. DAY 9 As Naomi heads into her office, her chatty ASSISTANT hand her an espresso.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: How was your weekend?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks Gloria. A sleek, large office. A row of Lucite deal trophies line shelf. Naomi clicks through her email with lightning speed. ERIN enters the office in a stylish suit, carrying a heav pitch book. Erin is 34, smart, pretty and athletic.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: San Fran good? Naomi keeps her eyes on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You read up on the companies? Which one stands out?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I was looking at--  6 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Cachet. I’ve got a hunch they’re looking to expand. You've got numbers on them? Erin glances down at her book. She does not have those numbers.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I will send them right over. Naomi nods and starts typing something. She notices Erin still standing there.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone's saying there’s going to be some movement around here... and I am wondering if this might be the time to--

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: No, not right now. Naomi’s fingers fly over the keyboard. Erin does not budg Naomi finally turns her full attention to her.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told you I’d make a push for you. And I will. But right now HR is out there snatching Blackberries.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I get that. But I’ve been under- compensated two years in a row.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: It’s a down year. And I am still getting feedback that you are... too nice.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Who says that?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Clients, for one.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: How can you be too nice to clients?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: (Sincerely) Erin, we will get you there. You have to trust me on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 7 Green Rev. (07/15/15) Erin nods.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need those numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin tries to stop herself from crying in a bathroom stal INT. ERIN’S OFFICE. NIGHT 10 A janitor pushes a mop down the quiet deserted hallway. O a few of the offices are lit. In one of them, Erin revises graphs in a smaller, but sti nicely-decorated office. She rubs her eyes, stretches her neck, and reaches for a plastic cup of green juice which has the word KALE scribb on it. She grimaces as she drinks. INT. NAOMI’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM. NIGHT 11 Naomi gets ready for bed, washing her face, taking out he diamond earrings. Her jewelry is neatly arranged in boxes from Tiffany's. She climbs into bed, switching on a flatscreen TV, clicki to resume an episode of Scandal. Her laptop BINGS. She mutes Scandal as she grabs the lapt and opens an attachment from Erin, labeled CACHET. She be expertly scanning the data.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi moves swiftly through the office, looking over the papers as she walks, Erin at her side.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: These are their latest projections? Naomi holds out a graph.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That can’t be right--

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I know, I just caught that.  13 14 8 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Who did this graph?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Teddy. I told you, he’s careless. Naomi stops abruptly. Turns so she can see in the distanc bunch of young Associates at their cubicles.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: When did they all start growing these mustaches?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I’m sure there’s a bet. TEDDY, 24, boyish with a hint of a mustache, laughs loudl projecting nothing but ease and confidence.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Who’s fucking kid is he again?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Nephew. Lawrence Sidel.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: The mustache? Erin smiles, reaching for the papers.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi walks briskly towards Randall's office. Out of the corner of her eye, she notices a 53 year old executive in nice suit carrying a box of belongings, flanked by two bu security guards. INT. RANDALL’S OFFICE. DAY 14 A gorgeous office with floor-to-ceiling windows. Many Luc trophies and framed portraits of bankers with executives.  9 Green Rev. (07/15/15) Naomi faces RANDALL, Global Head of Equity Capital Market late 50s, imposing, deliberate. He’s been at the top for long time. A perky HR WOMAN, early 30’s, stands nearby, flipping thr a file, and watching Randall, who stares at a small tower Jenga blocks on his gleaming desk. Naomi waits, on edge. Randall carefully pulls out a Jenga block. The tower bare trembles.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Naomi. Thanks for coming in.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Of course. Naomi glances at the HR woman.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: You know Leslie, from HR. She needs a couple more names, from your department. Naomi relaxes almost imperceptibly, nods.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Teddy Sidel, and Arthur Abbott.

dialogues.speaker: HR WOMAN
dialogues.text: You do know who Teddys’s uncle is?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You asked me to identify the weakest performers. What you do with that information is up to you. HR Woman smirks, nods to Randall, and goes.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: I’m sure you’ve heard the talk. I’m gettin out. Retiring.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: You never want to stay too late at the party. He gestures to the trophies around the office.  15 10 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this particular party is sobering up. Randall turns back to his blocks.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your turn. Naomi looks at him, a bit surprised. She reaches for one the blocks and pushes it gently.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Steady now. Naomi pulls the block out; the tower remains intact.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: So they’1l be naming a new group head. He looks her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Look, Naomi, I’m going to be frank with you. This doesn’t look like your year.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Because of Dynacorps.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: I’ve asked around about what happened there. The perception is... that you rubbed some people the wrong way. Naomi’s face is unreadable; she does not want to betray h true feelings. Randall does not look away from her.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're looking for a rainmaker. Naomi smiles tightly. We begin to hear the sounds of punching, grunting. INT. NAOMI’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 15 Naomi kickboxes violently, her TRAINER meeting every blow with his pads. Sweat runs down her face.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER
dialogues.text: You’re hesitating! Go, go, go!!!  16 11 Green Rev. (07/15/15) She freezes for a second, then lunges forward with a prim scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi refills her scotch and hands one to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I mean at least hit me with facts. Use my numbers against me, but perception-- what the fuck do I do with that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You never really told me, what happened with Dynacorps.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I’m sure you read the tweets. Apparently I wore the wrong outfit. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The truth is I don’t know. And it’s my fucking alarm clock. Three, four in the morning, I’m asking myself-- what the fuck happened?? Replaying the negotiations in my head, the valuation, the pricing. I’ve been in hundreds of those meetings and I’ve never had one go south. He looks at her, surprised she is being so candid with hi

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t do that, right? Men don’t lose sleep over this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh we do. But we don’t turn on ourselves. More fun to be pissed at someone else. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the biggest deal you could get. Right now.  17 12 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Cachet just hired their 12th board member.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So they’re looking to go public. She nods, tasting the adrenaline of her next pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I found vc’s for that kid when he had five employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An lofty space lined with bookshelves and high windows. Naomi mingles effortlessly, laughing and chatting with an ethnically diverse crowd of women, mostly in their 20s. S is a star, but an approachable one, with women clamoring talk to her. SAMANTHA, beautiful, tough, and smartly dressed, watches Naomi from across the room. She is familiar with Naomi’s charisma. She chooses her moment to approach.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Naomi Bishop? Naomi turns, smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Samantha Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I thought you hated alumni events!

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Well, you know. Important to give back. Especially to mentor the-- She turns, noticing a large sign reading “City Women,” wi cartoon drawing of a giant high heel climbing a building.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that the logo? Sam laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I think these young women look at me like what not to do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like how to go to law school and still end up broke.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: There must be at least one young idealist out there. How are things? You’re still at the US Attorney's, locking up the drug dealers?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m actually in your area now. White collar crime. Securities division.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Well, good for you.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And you're still

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: at Remson? I'm a lifer. Golden handcuffs. You got a file on us?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I imagine we’ve got a file on everybody. They are smiling, but this hangs in the air a moment. SAM (CONT’D) Let’s get that drink we always swear we will and never do. I know, you're very busy-

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Let’s do it. It’s been too long.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’1l call-- your have people? Naomi just smiles at this. INT. MENTORING EVENT SPACE. Faces of various women, as together Asian YOUNG WOMAN people. You do

dialogues.speaker: EVENING 18
dialogues.text: they listen intently. A put- takes the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m wondering, for each of you, what’s that thing that really makes you want to get up in the morning?  19 14 Green Rev. (07/15/15) Naomi, Samantha, and three other women face the audience.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I guess the simplest answer is: I like money. Some people laugh nervously, but the women in the audienc are loving this. Sam listens.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do. I mean that’s the honest answer. I like numbers, I like a challenge, I love negotiation. But let's just be clear. I really like money. I like knowing I have it. I grew up without money, in a house where there was never enough. I was raised by a single mom with four kids. I took my first job on Wall Street so I could pay for my little brothers to go to college. Remson gave me that chance and I’ve been there ever since. Naomi sees a woman nodding sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’m not going to stand here and tell you I only do what I do so I can take care of other people. Because it is okay to do it for ourselves. For how it makes us feel. Secure? Yes. Powerful? When you understand VALUE, COST, what we will pay for, what we will risk, and what we can build? That’1l get you up in the morning. Sam leans forward now, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m glad it’s acceptable now for women to talk openly about ambition. But don’t let money be a dirty word. We can like that too. EXT. U.S. ATTORNEY’S OFFICE. DAY People swarm up the courthouse steps.  20 21 15 Green Rev. (07/15/15) INT. U.S. ATTORNEY’S OFFICE. DAY Sam reviews a spreadsheet in the spare space, under fluorescent lights. Her colleague, FRANK, 40's, a guy from like it is, appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: 20 and somewhat cluttered Brooklyn who calls it You go to the thing? You talk to her? Your friend?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And? She give you anything on the hedge fund guy?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen the woman in 5 years. What is it you think she’s going to give me, during our appearance at a Vassar alumni reception?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Look, this was your idea to get to the bank this way.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I said I would make contact.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I made contact. He just stares at her. She gives hima reaches for a stack of files and opens INT. U.S. ATTORNEY’S OFFICE. NIGHT Samantha munches a Snickers bar as she spreadsheets, memos, and reports. confident smile. She the one on top. 21 pours over She scribbles names and numbers on a legal pad -- “Remson “Michael Connor” “Titanite.”  22 23 16 Green Rev. (07/15/15) INT. NAOMI’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT 22 The kitchen is open to the living room. Naomi opens her fridge, revealing immaculate shelves. A bottle of wine, a couple of takeout containers, a giant bag of carrots. She grabs a box of upscale fish food. She turns to a square tank containing a spectacular beta fish, and sprinkles the food into the water. The tank see unusually large for such a small creature. INT. ERIN’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM. NIGHT 23 Erin packs haphazardly by the light of her phone. Her hus GABE, 35, groans from the bed. He’s charming, smart, and to-earth.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What time’s your car coming?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Jesus. You need to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Please don’t tell me what I need.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I get it, you have to win the bake sale. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Bake off.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Bring me a brownie?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: A brownie? I’m bringing home the fucking bakery. She climbs into bed.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I hope I never have to battle you for anything.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you’d lose!  24 25

dialogues.speaker: A26
dialogues.text: 17. Green Rev. (07/15/15) He grabs her, pulling her to him.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing, between kisses) 4:30!!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AIRPORT. DAY, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: The plane touches down. Quick montage of images of San Francisco: the sloping streets, Chinatown, the trolley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi opens the door of her room to Erin, who holds out a stack of papers. Erin stifles a yawn. Erin nods,

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: New specs.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you need?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I need my team to stay awake for the pitch tomorrow. Go on, get some rest. grateful.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: They do have a whole menu of pillows here.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I'd go with number five.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Good choice. Soft edges, firm at the core.  26 18 Green Rev. (07/15/15) She turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy and BILL, a young African-American Associate, take peek at Naomi and Erin who practice the pitch behind glas doors. Bill leans in to Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What do you think she makes?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Five fifty base.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Okay, but what’s the bonus? I mean it’s true, right, the girls get less? Teddy sees that Naomi and Erin are emerging through the g doors.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: And here they are. Game time ladies! Naomi just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You know what's fascinating about you, Teddy? You are a survivor. He looks at her quizzically. Erin tries to hide a smile. A team of men in stunning suits goes past them, chuckling

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Was that Channing? Teddy nods.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: My uncle says Remson’s eyeing that tall guy. For next Global Head. He trails off, unnerved by Naomi’s steely gaze.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Boys, we have a pitch to give. She is focused, like an athlete just before a game.  27 19 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A less corporate, funkier conference room than those we h seen. On the wall, a giant gold key made up of lines of c The CEO, ED, 29, is flanked by his CFO, IAN, a numbers wi who protects Ed like a younger brother, at the head of a table crowded with casually dressed managers. Ed still ha the look of a kid who plays too many video games. Restles energy pulses under his casual exterior. Teddy and Bill distribute pitch books. Erin notices that pens say “Channing Trust,” left behind by the competition She casually flicks one into a nearby trashcan as Naomi begins the pitch. Naomi lives for this; she is in her element.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, if you wanted privacy, if you wanted to send a secret message, you made invisible ink with vinegar. Teddy proudly displays a large seemingly blank piece of poster board.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when you were ready to “go public” you revealed your message with grape juice. Bill takes a large paintbrush dipped in grape juice and “paints” across the posterboard. The Remson logo appears purple as he does this. People are nodding, smiling. They appreciate this touch. Naomi sees Ian and a few others opening the pitch book, a gives a silent go-ahead to Erin. Numbers time.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: But Cachet has certainly taken privacy to the next level, and we are so pleased to have the chance to foster that growth. If you open your books to page 2, you’ll see in the first model, that we are predicting a valuation of $820 million at 34 to 36 a share. Ian and Ed flip through the graphs and models.  28 29 30 20 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Well, you’re certainly presenting us with some compelling numbers...

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You guys can see we’ve done our homework. But that’s not why you’re going to give us this deal.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I remember what you told me the first day we met: we’re not a social media company with privacy settings, we’re a privacy company that can build a social network. An impenetrable social network. I understood that. The NEED for that. I felt it in my gut. Some people thought you guys were paranoid, investors wouldn't go for it. Now fast forward: Edward Snowden, nude photos of actresses, the Sony hack. Your revenue jumps. Your competitors start rolling out. But we were ahead of the curve. Because we understood that every day it gets harder to trust people in this world. And security is the hottest commodity around. Ed is nodding. Ian looks impressed. Others are too. Erin catches Naomi’s eye. They’ve got this.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AIRPORT. DAY, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: An airplane touches down in New York. INT. NAOMI’S OFFICE. DAY 30 Naomi’s fingers fly over the keyboard. Financial news pla in the background, muted. The phone rings and she grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Naomi.  31 32 33 21 Green Rev. (07/15/15) A moment. She breaks into a wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well I am glad to hear that. We see the IPO Reporter on the television screen in her office, then start to hear:

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: In tech news, get out your IPO calendar-- As we CUT TO INT. ERIN’S OFFICE. DAY 31 Erin holds a plank pose on her elbows, hovering over her blackberry. A message pops up and her eyes light up as sh jumps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: The privacy company Cachet is going public. Cachet has been seeing record growth recently in the wake of the public’s keen interest in security. INT. SAM’S OFFICE. DAY 32 Sam watches the coverage at her desk, chewing on a pen.

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: The lead banker on the deal is said to be Naomi Bishop. INT. NAOMI’S OFFICE. DAY 33 We are back on Naomi watching her TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: IPO REPORTER
dialogues.text: Apparently some money managers were surprised to hear this news, after Bishop was reported to ruffle some feathers during a tech IPO earlier this year-- Naomi, unfazed, reaches over and switches off the news.  34 22 Green Rev. (07/15/15) INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 34 Naomi eyes are on her BlackBerry. Michael playfully takes from her, replacing it with a champagne glass. They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You know what’s funny about the privacy space? Half the world is paranoid and the other half never even resets their passwords.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: It’s true.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: For 20 years, my password for everything was Rudolphl.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Like the reindeer?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I had a dog. When I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Ahww.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What about you? Lamest password?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I’m not telling you my passwords.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Old ones. Circa 1996.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Bankerchick.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Now that is hot. He grabs her roughly for a kiss. She presses against him, smelling him, unzipping him as THE BUZZER sounds.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: (Frustrated) That’s Erin.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Who? Naomi buttons her blouse as Michael zips up.  23 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: My VP, she’s dropping off the revisions. She presses the buzzer button.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Amused) You buzz people up to my apartment now? Naomi opens the door. Erin approaches awkwardly holding o pile of binders.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Erin, nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Hi, sorry-- Naomi takes the binders.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Goodnight! Naomi shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where were we? He pulls Naomi to him and tosses her onto the couch. They move fast, frantic for each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The early morning light streaks through the window. Naomi twisted over Michael asleep on the couch. We hear:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey babe. It’s me. You were a tiger last night. Am I seeing you later?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You’re calling me on this line?  36 24 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and ABBY, a stylish compliance lawyer, listen to a recording.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey compliance! FYI. This is a strictly personal phone call.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Michael -- we can’t be -- Sam realizes it is Naomi she’s listening to. She leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You guys monitoring? You hear anything about clients? ‘Cause the only wall we’re crossing is... THE WALL OF LOVE. There is muffled laughter in the background, as if someon the trading floor is egging him on.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You are an idiot. Abby clicks off the recording.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Never a dull moment here in compliance.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That’s his company phone? Is that crossing the wall? I mean she’s on the banking side--

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Well technically there’s nothing criminal here--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Remson doesn’t have a policy prohibiting this kind of romantic--

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Some banks do, but nope.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And what’s your gut about this guy?  37 25 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Michael? He’s got instincts. Some people have instincts and some people are getting a tip.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We keep an eye on him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Frank mentioned you used to be an AUSA? You ever miss it?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Wearing the white hat? Sure. But you know what they say, you can’t spread ideals on a cracker.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do you actually know people who say that? Abby smiles politely. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. MORNING 37 Michael makes espresso as a half-dressed Naomi making her down the stairs. He goes to her, plays with her hair.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What’s that? He touches a tiny patch of reddish skin, barely visible j below her jawline. She fingers it.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Nothing. She begins to delicately put on her diamond earrings. He admires her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Remind me why I didn’t marry you.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Diamonds. He looks curious.  26 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remson Holiday party. Ninety- something. Randall introduced us.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The St. Regis. Naomi indicates the earrings.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You asked me who bought these. And I saw you, gearing up to fight off some rival. But then I told you I bought them for myself. After my dad left I watched my mom leave her best earrings at the pawn shop. We never got them back. So I wanted to be able to buy enough diamonds for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You never told me that. She smiles as if at an unspoken memory.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: But men like a girl they can take care of.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Someone should warn them about the alimony. Naomi laughs. She pulls on her heels.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You’re more fun divorced anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well congrats again. People seem to like Cachet. You remember my buddy Marco?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: From Stanford. The tech blog guy?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: He’s always writing about privacy. Encryption, whisper-phones, all kinds of spy shit. Cachet could be big.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: We certainly hope so.  38 27 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I mean you think these Cachet guys are onto something. She looks at him, suddenly cautious.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: We do.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Due diligence started yet?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You want a Chinese Wall in my living room? I didn’t ask you anything.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I just think it’s simpler, not to talk shop.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You think that some of the time. She looks at him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean if it’s about you, your prospects at the firm, you’re happy to talk shop.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: That’s completely different.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Okay. She set down her cup very deliberately.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I am going to go to work now. She goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wine flows into glasses, and fingers reach for hors d’‘oe Naomi, Erin, Teddy, Bill and a few others celebrate the d They are toasting and doing shots. Naomi looks relaxed, carefree.  39 28 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m telling you. Photos of Ed and all his programmers. Hanging out in a hot tub. Bill holds out his phone to Teddy. Erin shakes her head, laughing. Naomi notices Randall crossing over to them from another table. They follow her gaze. Teddy starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: No no, don’t get up. I’m with a client. I just wanted to say congratulations. Great work, all of you.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Thank you. She makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know Erin-- He doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: She did really spectacular work on this.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Always good to know. Again, congratulations. Erin smiles, pleased, as Randall shakes her hand. RANDALL (CONT’D) I recommend the porterhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin heads to the sink, holding a martini glass with an o half hidden by her purse. She pours out the drink and beg filling the glass with tap water. The door swings open. Naomi. Erin meets her gaze in the mirror. Erin finishes filling the glass.  40 41 29 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: How far along are you?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: It’s really early. Six weeks. Naomi nods, smiles tightly.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Well. It’s very exciting. Congratulations. She disappears into a stall. Erin takes a deep breath and heads back to the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the table. The men devour steaks, Naomi finishes salad.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Look, anyone can make money selling information, but here was a guy who thought it was more valuable to protect it. She looks at Erin, noticing she has barely touched her porterhouse steak.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean we all understand the value of privacy. Erin looks up, a flicker of anger as she meets Naomi’s pointed gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Information is power. Bill and Teddy don’t quite understand the sudden tension.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Fuck yea. INT. ERIN’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT 4l Erin aggressively tears open a giant box, as Gabe looks u from his newspaper.  30 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Did Naomi think you were going to call her the minute you peed on the stick?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She aggressively tears open the box, clothes spill out.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You think she wishes she had kids?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. I don’t think all women wish they had kids. What is all this                         Erin pulls a long mumu thing out of the box, dangling it from her.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Clothes. Maternity. My sister sent them--

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: You told her?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I’m excited. You know my family, we get excited. Erin shoves the clothing back in the box.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I’m not ready for this.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: We really should get longer to prepare. The Alpine Salamander is pregnant for three years.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: That sounds horrible!

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: My eight graders are obsessed with them. After sex the female stores the sperm in this “semen pouch” --

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Ew! But she is laughing.  42 31 Green Rev. (07/15/15) INT. SAM’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 42 A cozy and colorful space crowded with well-loved furnish and toys strewn about. Sam perches on a kitchen stool, scrolling through her lap SOPHIE, 6, pours milk sloppily into a glass held by her t WILLIAM. Sam’s wife, MELANIE, an African-American woman with the strong, graceful body of a dancer, tugs on her boots.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Which babysitter?? Sam peers at an online pic of Benji Akers, 40s, snowboard under a headline which reads: WOULD YOU TRUST THIS MAN WI

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Hello! Sam! Sam finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sophie wants to know who’s watching them tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Lisa from downstairs--

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I HATE Lisa--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You don’t hate Lisa--

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She’s got weird hair.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: She’s not a REAL babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: They've got a point-- I mean you know I have rehearsal every Tuesday...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Something came up-- it happens!  43 32 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Drinks. With some friend from childhood?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I told you-- it’s work.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What, you're investigating her? Is this one of your Kalinda Sharma undercover routines?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Lisa is fine. She’s affordable. And you -- She reaches out to pull the twins in for a playful squeez SAM (CONT’D) You crazies like the games on her phone. Sam kisses the giggling twins.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Quality child care. But she can’t help but smile at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Naomi drink colorful cocktails. Naomi admires a picture of Sam’s kids on Sam’s phone.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: They're terrific. She hands the phone back. A beat. Sam seems a little unsu how to reciprocate the small talk. Naomi gestures at her phone.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got nieces, nephews and a Beta. Sam laughs awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a fish.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I...  33. Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: So, you’re a mom, you're a lesbian, what else is new? Sam laughs again, less awkward.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And I do yoga now.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Of course you do. I’1l tell my brother I saw you. He thinks every girl he ever dated turned gay. Sam smiles fondly.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How is Pete? And the rest of your family? Everybody still in Michigan?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Yes. In that 30 mile radius. They're fine. Naomi finishes her drink, notices Sam checking out the fe bartender.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you seeing anyone?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I get what I need.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah? Do tell. I’m just a boring married lady. Someone from work?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Where else. Sam nods. She is trying to figure out how to play this.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I dated a colleague once, but it got claustrophobic.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: We don’t see each other day-to-day.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Smart. So what, a broker? Naomi looks at her.  34 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Yes, actually.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Huh. Does that cause any...

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Any...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I mean there must be certain things you can’t share--

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Here I thought we were just two old friends having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Could we get the check please? (To Sam) His name is Michael Connor. But maybe you already know that.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. I mean -- She looks at Naomi. Nothing is getting by this woman. SAM (CONT’D) Ok. I did come across his name recently, in the office. As somebody who--

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Who--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Works with a lot of hedge funds.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Yes. That is what he does. Naomi puts a $100 bill down and stands to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (STOCK FOOTAGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conference room buzzes with people, mostly men, inclu Ed and Ian. Conversation quiets as Naomi and her team str into the room. Naomi notices MARIN, a woman with purple h whisper something to the CFO and hurry out of the room. Naomi takes a seat next to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, everyone. We'd like to start off with a preliminary discussion of pricing--

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Let’s do it. Where are we at?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: At this point, we’re looking at a range of $32 to $34 a share. At 7.2 million shares, that gives us a valuation of 868 million--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Now just a minute here--

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: We gotta have a billion valuation.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: We've looked at the comparables, and--

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You said $34 to $36 in the pitch. You’re going to leave tens of millions of dollars on the table.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: We can get at least 35. Naomi hesitates. She needs this to go smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: (diplomatically) Well it’s a balancing act. Raising money for the company, while still promising the investors a deal for coming on board... A couple of men at the table exchange looks with each oth as things get more heated.  36 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Look, you begged me for this IPO. You want me to call Channing Trust?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Ed, what we want to avoid is a down round--

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: We know what happened with your last IPO.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s relevant here-- All eyes are on Naomi. Erin speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Ed, I believe our goal here is to find the right number for all of us. Ed turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: The number is 35. Erin glances briefly at Naomi, as if asking permission. N nods almost imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Possibly. But you can think of it like a party. We need to encourage people to show up to the party. Could be the best party in the world, but if nobody shows up--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: A party?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: We don’t need to--

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: No, hang on. I get this. A party. Go on--

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: The $32 to $34 range will get people in the door. But if the party is good enough--  46

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: People will line up around the block.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: This is true. Ed addresses Erin as if she’s the only person in the room

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I like you. He smiles. Ian looks apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how to talk to people. I‘1l party with you anytime.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. She smiles back at him. Naomi watches.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So if we're talking about selling 15% of the company now, we should discuss what options that gives us going forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi, in silk pajamas, nibbles room service strawberries she reviews a due diligence checklist. She closes it and flips through open tabs on her computer: a bio of Ed, A l of best dermatologists in NYC, and a Soul Cycle class schedule. She glances up at the TV, playing silently over the bed. Suddenly she fixes her eyes on the screen. She scrambles for the remote control, turning up the volu On the TV:

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Footage of a crowd of people and yellow police tape at th foot of a midtown building.  47 38 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: ...in Midtown Manhattan, where a young man employed at the hedge fund Treem Capital jumped from his 24th floor office window this afternoon. A source tells Bloomberg News that the firm has been under investigation for insider trading... Naomi watches, disturbed. She goes to the minibar and pul out a small bottle of scotch and a bag of M&Ms. Her eyes still on the screen, she begins popping M&Ms into her mou one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam scribbles on a large whiteboard with a cluster of nam and arrows: “Michael,” “Titanite Capital.” The photo of B on his snowboard is tacked up next to his name. Frank pokes his head in, sees Sam crossing out “NAOMI”

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How was drinks? She just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She’s not going to give me anything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If we don’t have a good feeling about this one--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We don’t need warm fuzzy fucking feelings. We need evidence. Did your friends in compliance send anything over? He hands her a thick envelope.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Paperwork on Michael. Sam opens the file, her eyes lighting up with interest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now don’t go doing anything rash. You’re not in narcotics anymore.  48 39 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael joins two hedge fund guys, BENJI, 40’s, the guy f the skiing picture and CORY, 35, a Benji-in-training, at VIP table in a swanky lounge.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Michael, I don’t know if you've ever met Cory? Michael and Cory shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s been with us a long time, but he’s ready to play with the big boys now. Cory tries to laugh this off. A provocatively dressed waitress pours Michael’s Scotch. smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What have you got for us?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m thinking privacy. He takes a napkin and writes the word Cachet on it in gre pen.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: (To Cory) His girlfriend's doing the IPO.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don't have a girlfriend. Benji smirks, picks up the napkin.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You with these green pens.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Color of money.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nothing. (His eyes twinkling a bit) It’s private. Benji nods, takes a drink. Turns to Cory.  40 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I was just outta school when I met this guy. And you know what I saw? He wasn’t doing it for the cash. He loved the game itself. And he played it like a pro. The day I left to start a hedge fund he sends a fucking hedgehog to my office. Michael smiles fondly.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: An actual hedgehog?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I open the box and this fuckin rodent is climbing into my lap. Benji leans forward, suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is that guy? Michael meets his gaze coolly.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're different lately. I don’t want to say older, but--

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We're all older. Cory nods at this.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I dunno. It’s something-- new regulations getting you down? He stands up, gathering his coat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know where you’re going with this--

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Because I’m still in. All the way. And we've got capital to invest. So you bring us something, yeah? Benji starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (To Cory) Let’s go.  41 Green Rev. (07/15/15) Cory follows, a bit like a puppy. Michael is left alone, staring after them. 49 INT. CACHET CONFERENCE ROOM. DAY ag Naomi and Erin sort through paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: These are the due diligence reports?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Yes, and they are uploaded to the data room and ready for counsel to review. Naomi catches sight of MARIN, the woman with purple hair, passing by the conference room, glancing at them through glass. Naomi leans over and whispers to Erin.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: What’s the story with that girl?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: She’s one of the programmers.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: That’s the fourth time she’s walked by this morning. Naomi watches through the glass as the Marin moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael scrolls through his phone while eating an ice cre cone. Samantha approaches, gives him a mysterious smile.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Michael Connor.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, have we...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Samantha Ryan. US attorney's office. He was not expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Really? Should I phone my lawyer?  42 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s necessary. I was just hoping we could have a brief chat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sure. That’s my idea of a perfect summer evening. Just a cozy chat with a long legged woman who just happens to be FBI.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I didn’t say FBI. He waves towards the street.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, they hang back in the van.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m alone. And I’m not interested in you. He leans forward. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well that is too bad.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m interested in one of your clients, Titanite. Benji Akers.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not sure how I can help you. My relationship with my clients is confidential.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Of course. But these hedge fund guys they’ve always got a loophole, some way of staying out of trouble. But they need a guy like you, right, at a big bank? And you don’t have so many loopholes. You’ve got regulations, compliance looking over your shoulder, handing me intell... So it seems to me, that if anybody’s gonna take the fall, it’s not going to be Benji Acres.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Take the fall for what?  51 43 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Exactly. Could be anything. Could be a merger last spring when it seemed like certain investors got the memo prematurely, or a bunch of trades that compliance flagged as a irregular... Michael looks at her, thoughtfully. He stands

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You don’t have anything on me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Because we’d be downtown, with wires and somebody in my face. This is just a cozy chat. Which I have certainly enjoyed. up.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you call me back when you've got some leverage.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Is that a challenge?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: If you like.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Look, you seem like one of the good guys. All I’m saying is, we can keep it that way. He gives her a nod and walks off into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi moves purposefully through a row of cubicles until sees Marin at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m with the bank handling the

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: I know. Naomi notices Marin wears a necklace made of shark teeth.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You guys talk to every single employee?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: No. You seem particularly interested in our process. In my experience, that usually means you have something you want to tell us.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: Wow. You’re good.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: So you do have something you want to tell us? Marin hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or you just like my shoes. Marin smiles. But then glances around nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: Not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi and Marin are in the shadows of the parking garage. Marin speaks quickly and glances around nervously. Naomi not sure what to make of her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: Cachet’s got its super secure social network, right. But here’s the thing. What happens if it gets hacked?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: It’s anonymized and encrypted at the highest level.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: You haven’t met my ex. He’s already done it once. We were beta testing, so it was actually kind of helpful. We plugged the holes. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans She looks 45 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: MARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he’ll keep trying. And there might be others.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: The challenge. The naked photos. Who knows. forward and continues quietly.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s called a man in the middle attack. Users want to be able to access the network on multiple devices. But that opens up the possibility of somebody implanting malware on the key server. around the park uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Does Ed know about this?

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: He thinks I’m paranoid. Which is pretty funny, when a company that’s built on paranoia thinks you're paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: But why tell me?

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: I want to sell my shares. You can help me with that, right? If this thing goes south? Naomi laughs.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: That’s not, what I do.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: I got plans. I’m starting a hackerspace. Marin looks around the park again. She notices a woman walking by with a big gold key on a necklace.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn’t hear me say that.  53 46 Green Rev. (07/15/15) And she scurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the restaurant, Naomi sees Erin and Ed sharin sushi, laughing together. Her blouse shows a little cleav Ed casually puts his hand on Erin’s shoulder. She smiles him.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Tasmanian sea trout? Ed and Erin look up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Naomi! Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: How’s the sushi?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Delicious. Erin pops a piece in her mouth. Naomi indicates Ed’s casu outfit.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I’m liking this look-- you’re going to be the rock star of this roadshow, and people are going to want a piece of that hoodie!

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Oh yea.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Ed, I want to make sure we are in good shape here before I leave for New York. Ed glances at Erin.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I am in very good shape.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Terrific. Just one thing I want to ask you about. I’m sure it’s nothing, but something’s come up during due diligence. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A rumor that your network, encrypted as it is, might still be vulnerable to a certain kind of hacker. Ed smiles warily.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Sounds like you met Marin.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Yes actually. We were interviewing employees, and--

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Unfortunately our business can attract some colorful characters.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You need your employees to be as much a firewall as your code.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Look, I can promise you we’ve never been hacked. In theory there’s a backd door to everything. But we stay one step ahead. That’s the game.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Terrific. She and Erin smile at him. He grins back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi and Erin walk and talk.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: You need me to look into this? I can take care of things here.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Well Ed certainly seems to think so. They stare at each other a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to preserve the relationship.  55 48 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Are you going to sleep with him?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: It's risky territory. When he comes on to you, and he will at this rate, you have to let him down very very gently. That’s how you preserve the relationship.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know how this works.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Okay then. They walk in chilly silence.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Coolly) Then maybe you can find a way to get him to sign an indemnity clause. If there is any vulnerability for investors here, we can’t be liable.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I’1l handle it. They are approaching the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: And Erin-- keep it quiet. There’s probably nothing here, and the last thing we need is rumors starting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam sits on the steps, delicately balancing a sandwich an giant ream of spreadsheets she is highlighting. Frank approaches with two coffees, and looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Titanite accounts from the last five years. He nods, but seems as interested in her sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The turkey’s better on a roll.  49 Green Rev. (07/15/15) He traces a column on the spreadsheet with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Deals where somebody might’ve known a little extra.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Always big pharma.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yep. Clinical trial. Somebody gets too cozy with the researchers. I’ve got my eye on the guy who managed the account. We might get him to talk. Sam’s cell phone rings. She grabs it. SAM (CONT’D) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HEADHUNTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi, is this Samantha Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes, who’s this?

dialogues.speaker: HEADHUNTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m calling with Marshall Bane and Associates. I have a client who is very interested in recruiting someone with your background and skill set--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (a bit confused) Wait-- I’m sorry, who’s your client?

dialogues.speaker: HEADHUNTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Right now we’re working with Channing Trust to fill an open position. You may know that they’ve been expanding their legal and compliance departments recently--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. Sure, I would like to hear more about that. Frank looks at her suspiciously. SAM (CONT’D) But I’m gonna have to call you back.  50 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: HEADHUNTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Certainly. Sam hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Which bank?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You never been called by a headhunter before? Well that’s why they call this place the departure lounge. I’m the only sucker who's been here more than a decade. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why do you stay?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just do me one favor before you talk to those guys. You been on a trading floor, right?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You gotta go there, see what we’re up against. You go, you breathe it in, the hunger of it. Pure American desire. And if you feel like you need a shower afterwards, well then you come back here.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And if I don’t? Need a shower? He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’1l send us a diamond crusted postcard.  51 Green Rev.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DECK OF COBALT COCKTAIL LOUNGE. EVENING
Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 Sam, now little dressed up, drinks a martini, subtly watc Cory, who sits with another HEDGE FUND GUY, who is talkin excitedly. Cory is nodding a lot, taking gulps of his dri and looking a little jittery. Hedge Fund Guy shakes Cory’s hand and leaves. Cory glance and catches Sam looking at him. She smiles coyly and make her way over to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Have we...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah... I think we've... Cory.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sam. Wait, It was a cocktail thing downtown...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yea... I think so. Sam sits down, brushing his leg a tiny bit.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And you were telling me about your work. Because you work at... Titans Fund--

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Titanite.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Which sounds so intense. You were saying how you have to bring a little something extra. This little bit of... what did you call it... edge?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sam leans forward, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam sets down an empty glass.  52 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Amazing. I can’t even balance my checkbook! But wait, last time I feel like you gave me a great example. It was like a clinical trial? I don’t remember the details.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: We talked about that? She giggles a little, puts a hand on his knee.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We were a little loose-lipped, if you know what I mean. And it wasn’t even the good stuff! She takes a sip of his drink. SAM (CONT’D) But yeah, you had done all this research and even talked to one of the scientists. It was for MS, right? That’s why I was so interested, because my mom has it. She watches him, to see if she’s taking this too far, but nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah, I remember that. Sorry--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: But the drug was a mess, right? The scientist, wait, he’s a big deal... I’ve read about him. What was his name? Dr. Soden?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Dr. Sobel. Sam smiles. This is the confirmation she was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Right, so he told you. And that’s how you get edge. He’s looking at her a little nervously now. She sees Benj enter the lounge. SAM (CONT’D) Will you call me sometime?  57 58 53 Green Rev. (07/15/15) She scribbles her full name and number on a napkin. She d into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi runs through the park in sleek workout clothes. She breathes hard, pushing herself. She glances behind her a couple of times. Why does she fe like someone is watching her? Someone runs up from behind, making her jump. It’s Michael, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: (laughing) Jesus! You’re stalking me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Some people nap after the redeye. Others run.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I can’t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: No. She starts up a slow run again. He joins her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I met an old friend of yours. Samantha. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I thought you could tell me. I’m not the one who’s besties with the US attorney. They run on together into the distance.  59

dialogues.speaker: 59A
dialogues.text: 60 54 Green Rev. (07/15/15) INT. SAM’S APARTMENT. DAWN 59 The buzz of Sam’s phone wakes her. She glances at it brie turns to admire a sleeping Melanie, gently pulling down t sheet and beginning to kiss her chest. Melanie murmurs encouragement, eyes still closed. Sam’s phone buzzes again, more insistently. This time she grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: This must be Cory. INT. CORY’S BEDROOM. DAY. INTERCUT SCENES 59A Cory paces in front of his window. He’s been up all night

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I googled you.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Of course you did.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You’re a fucking prosecutor?!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'd like to hear more about your contact with Dr. Sobel--

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You can talk to my lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I look forward to it. She hangs up, eyes on Melanie, who has gone back to sleep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A golf cart delivers Naomi to where JOHN, her mentor, mid 50s, exuding a relaxed confidence, stands overlooking an entire golf course. He greets her with open arms.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Naomi!  61 55 Green Rev. (07/15/15) She kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to play? Cause I didn’t waste a dozen Sundays teaching you strokes for you to ride around in a cart.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You’re not playing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I play. I own the fucking place. It’s boring as shit. The playing, the owning, give me a fucking break. She smiles. She truly loves this guy. He’s the father she never had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Naomi walk over the green.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's a tricky one. A disgruntled employee is not the most reliable source.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: I know. And she’s backpedaling. Now she won’t give me anything concrete.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: And on paper--

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Everything looks perfect. Our IT guys at Remson and they think this network is as airtight as they’ve seen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So what’s the problem? She looks at him. Not sure if she wants to open up. But t is why she’s come.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: There’s just this nagging feeling...  62 56 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: In your gut.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: You taught me to trust my gut. But I don’t want to make the wrong move here. He nods, thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That sounds like fear. Which is not the same as instinct. You know why this is a business for the young? It’s not the physical stamina. It’s the complete lack of doubt.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: So I should keep it going.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m not going to tell you what to do, Naomi. But if the numbers check out, then it sounds like we're talking about a rumor here. And rumors... they’re the wildcard. You can’t control ‘em. And once you let em inside your head, well then who the fuck knows.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Must be nice. To not have to give a shit any more.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I never really gave a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam confronts Cory and ATTORNEY CAHN. Cory looks hungover

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We both know your client crossed the line.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY CAHN
dialogues.text: Look at him! He’s a dad! The man works 80 hours a week. He raises money for leukemia--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Does he plant daffodils too?  63 57 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY CAHN
dialogues.text: He has no history, he’s never been flagged by you guys, or the SEC.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you saying he doesn’t know any better? I have a six-year-old kid, she knows better. When you, and your boss, and your friends, decide to sabotage a company. When you get information that regular Joe Investor couldn’t possibly access, and you profit from that information while Joe Investor loses 65% of his retirement fund? You know better.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY CAHN
dialogues.text: Are you charging my client or not?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That depends.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY CAHN
dialogues.text: He’s not the one you want. There are bigger fish at Titanite.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And he’s prepared to cooperate? Cory’s tired face, bloodshot eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John touches Naomi’s arm as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey-- you've got this. She looks at him, grateful.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something. What would you have done? If I got pregnant when I was working for you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Bought you the latest stroller.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: No really. You wouldn’t have been disappointed? Off the record. Would you have kept pushing for me?  64 58 Green Rev. (07/15/15) He eyes her warily.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Of course. What else are you going to say? Well I’m not afraid to say it. It makes a girl weak. Distracted. John softens.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Naomi--

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: It gives her perspective. That other things matter. She looks at him, forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randall stares out the window at the city. He turns sharp as Naomi steps through the door.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: What the fuck happened this time?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: I got a call from Ed. It appears you’ve managed to rub him the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: We were doing our due diligence.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Cachet has provided you with all the necessary documents? And nobody's flagged anything.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: No, but--

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: What’s the fucking problem? Ed’s losing patience fast-- he thinks you lack confidence in this IPO. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I ask you again, what’s the fucking problem? Naomi takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: There is no problem. I have absolute confidence in this IPO.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I’ve got a roadshow to launch. She strides out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, on the phone and trying to balance a green juice an file of papers, navigates the garage, looking for the sta

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You pissed off Ed.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Wait-- I pissed him off? INT. NAOMI’S OFFICE. DAY 65A Naomi flips through messages. INTERCUT SCENES

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: What happened? I told you, you have to handle a guy like this very gently.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: What happened was I got him to sign the indemnity clause.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: What? He did?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Because I handled him very, very gently.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: (Chilly) Well then. Good work.  66 67 60 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Naomi hangs up. Her assistant pokes her head in.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Did you want me to reschedule that dermatologist for after the trip? Naomi stares at her like she has no idea what she’s talki about.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam gets a text from Cory: GREENSLEEVES PUB, 43rd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael drains a scotch. Benji walks in and tosses him a tied with a bow.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Happy birthday. Michael tears it open. Inside is a large stuffed animal hedgehog. Michael laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Very cute.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I don’t know, he may have gone a bit soft. He grins, amused at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are we on this Cachet thing? I saw the IPO calendar. Think it’s solid?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m working on it. Benji nods. Takes a long look at Michael.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You doing any of that botox? For the eyelids? Because I got a guy.  68 69 70 71 61 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’1l bear that in mind. Benji nods.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You know my cousin Evan?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: He’s at PJ Ellis?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Not anymore. Worked there 30 years. Regulations come along, he can’t get his numbers, they push him out.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s awful.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Now he’s knocking on my door, am I looking to hire somebody? Fucking tragedy. Michael reaches for the last of his scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam peers in the window of the pub and snaps a quick phot Benji and Michael. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 69 Michael rubs his eyes at the computer. A box appears on t screen: “This is a secure data room. PASSWORD:---------- ” Michael stares at the screen. He tries a few variations of “Bankerchick” with no succes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi and her team enter a room filled with men in suits.  72 73 74 75 76 62 Green Rev. (07/15/15)

dialogues.speaker: THE FREEWAYS OF L.A., (STOCK FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: Title card: LOS ANGELES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same Conference Room with new production design and n extras. The Cachet logo of the gold key made up of code. Ed and Ian, flanked by Naomi and Erin, address a crowd of in suits munching cookies.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Cachet is not a social network with privacy settings...

dialogues.speaker: LONDON BRIDGE, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: Title card: LONDON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same Conference Room with new production design and n extras.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We are a privacy company with a social network. More men in suits. Tea and biscuits. Erin displays a graph of revenue, Ian looking on. Ed pose for a selfie. Bill leans over to Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Dude, my dad keeps texting me. He wants a piece of Cachet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
